title: Paper: Midwifery FQE January 2024
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Community Health Nursing (Midwifery) - January 2024

questions.question: A woman comes to the antenatal clinic for her first ANC visit and reports that her Last Menstrual Period (LMP) was 24/12/2021. Her Expected Date of Delivery (EDD) will be on:
questions.explanation: Using Naegele's Rule: Add 7 days to the first day of LMP (24 + 7 = 31), subtract 3 months (Dec - 3 = Sept), and add 1 year (2021 + 1 = 2022). Result: 31st September. Since September has only 30 days, the date rolls over to 1st October 2022.
questions.hint: Add 7 days, subtract 3 months, add 1 year. Watch out for the number of days in September.

questions.question: Match the obstetric terms in Column A with their correct definitions in Column B:

pairs.right: A woman who has had only one delivery
A woman who has never delivered

questions.explanation: Nullipara: Never delivered (Para 0). Primipara: Has delivered once (Para 1).
questions.hint: Nulli means none, Primi means first/one.

questions.question: Match the obstetric terms in Column A with their correct definitions in Column B:

pairs.right: A woman who has had six or more deliveries
A woman who has had two or more deliveries

questions.explanation: Multipara: Delivered 2 or more times. Grand Multipara: Typically defined as 5 or more, but in this context match 'six or more'.
questions.hint: Multi means many, Grand means distinctively large number.

questions.question: The nutritional supplement given to women during preconception care to prevent neural tube defects is:
questions.explanation: Folic acid (Folate) supplementation before conception and during the first trimester significantly reduces the risk of neural tube defects like spina bifida.
questions.hint: It is essentially Vitamin B9.

questions.question: The hormones responsible for the regeneration and proliferation of the endometrium during each menstrual cycle, after menstruation has taken place are the:
questions.explanation: Estrogens (specifically estradiol, but 'Estrogens' is the broader correct category used here) stimulate the proliferative phase of the endometrial cycle.
questions.hint: This hormone dominates the first half (proliferative phase) of the cycle.

questions.question: Urinary tract infection in pregnancy usually results from:

options.text: An increase in the renin- angiotensin mechanism
Dilation and kinking of ureters brought about by the effect of progesterone hormone on them
The growing uterus makes it difficult for the woman to properly wipe herself

questions.explanation: Progesterone causes smooth muscle relaxation, leading to dilation and stasis of urine in the ureters, which provides a medium for bacterial growth.
questions.hint: Think about the hormonal effect on smooth muscles causing stasis.

questions.question: Pica is usually a sign of __________ in pregnancy.
questions.explanation: Pica (craving non-food items like soil or ice) is strongly associated with Iron Deficiency Anemia.
questions.hint: It relates to a deficiency of a key mineral for blood.

questions.question: While evaluating urine output for a mother in shock, the midwife is concerned if the urine output is:
questions.explanation: Oliguria (<30ml/hr) indicates inadequate renal perfusion and is a cardinal sign of shock.
questions.hint: The kidneys need perfusion to produce urine; think of the minimum hourly threshold.

questions.question: Which of the following sign may help a midwife diagnose shoulder dystocia in labor ward?

options.text: The fetal head remains tightly stuck in the vagina
The anterior shoulder is delivered but the posterior one is stuck
The chin retracts and depresses the perineum
Traction of the head delivers the shoulder

questions.explanation: The 'Turtle Sign' occurs when the fetal head retracts against the perineum after emergence because the shoulders are impacted.
questions.hint: Think of a turtle pulling its head back into its shell.

questions.question: The first manoeuvre a nurse would choose in the management of shoulder dystocia is:
questions.explanation: McRoberts maneuver (hyper-flexing maternal thighs) is the first-line intervention as it is non-invasive and highly effective in opening the pelvic outlet.
questions.hint: It involves changing the mother's leg position.

questions.question: Pressure exerted on amniotic fluid during uterine contractions is called:
questions.explanation: According to Pascal's law, pressure applied to a contained fluid is transmitted equally in all directions. In the uterus, this is General Fluid Pressure.
questions.hint: It affects the entire fluid volume equally.

questions.question: Immediately after placenta is delivered, the Nurse must do the following:

options.text: Place the placenta in a kidney dish
Massage the uterus and expel clots

questions.explanation: The immediate priority is to ensure the uterus contracts to prevent Postpartum Hemorrhage. Massaging the fundus is the critical step.
questions.hint: What prevents bleeding immediately?

questions.question: To deliver the posterior shoulder, the midwife:

options.text: Holds the baby by the parietals and pulls directly towards herself
Applies slight upward traction and moves baby’s head upward
Applies slight downward traction by moving baby’s head posteriorly
Holds the baby’s back and chest and pulls outwards

questions.explanation: Downward traction delivers the anterior shoulder; Upward traction delivers the posterior shoulder.
questions.hint: Think about the curve of the birth canal - lifting up helps the back shoulder clear the perineum.

questions.question: Intrauterine factors that enhance a newborn's ability to breath at birth:

options.text: Good uterine contractions which expel baby quickly
Presence of foetal breathing movements and foetal lung maturity
Adequate oxygenation and nutrition during pregnancy
Strong foetal axis pressure and a quick delivery

questions.explanation: Fetal breathing movements (practice) and surfactant production (maturity) are the physiological preparations for breathing.
questions.hint: The baby 'practices' and produces surfactant.

questions.question: Immediate action after baby’s head is born should be:

options.text: Measure two finger breadths, clamp and cut the cord
Check for cord round the neck, wipe baby’s mouth, nose, and face

questions.explanation: Before delivering the shoulders, check for nuchal cord and clear the airway if necessary.
questions.hint: Safety check before the rest of the body comes out.

questions.question: When the fontanelles are bulging, this implies that there is:
questions.explanation: Bulging fontanelles indicate high pressure inside the skull (e.g., meningitis, hydrocephalus). Depressed fontanelles indicate dehydration.
questions.hint: Pressure pushing out.

questions.question: The reflex that is elicited when the corner of the baby’s mouth is stroked, baby turns his/her head and opens mouth is referred to as:
questions.explanation: The rooting reflex helps the newborn find the nipple for feeding.
questions.hint: Searching for food (roots).

questions.question: A ridge between upper and lower uterine segments, visible above the symphysis pubis is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Bandl's ring is a pathological retraction ring visible on the abdomen, indicating obstructed labor.
questions.hint: It is a warning sign of rupture.

questions.question: One of the following is a danger sign during puerperium:
questions.explanation: Headache with dizziness can indicate postpartum pre-eclampsia/eclampsia or severe anemia. Watery discharge is lochia serosa/alba (normal), warm breasts are engorgement (common), lax muscles are normal initially.
questions.hint: It relates to blood pressure or blood loss.

questions.question: Lochia on the first four days after delivery is characterized as:

options.text: Reddish with some pieces of tissue
Serous with some brown tinged mucus

questions.explanation: Lochia Rubra (Red) lasts for the first 3-4 days.
questions.hint: Rubra implies red.

questions.question: The risks associated with prematurity include:

options.text: Infections, asphyxia, malformation of the gut

questions.explanation: Premature infants have immature lungs (Asphyxia), poor temp control (Hypothermia), and fragile brain vessels (IVH). Malformations are congenital, not caused by prematurity itself.
questions.hint: Think about immature organ functions, not defects.

questions.question: Effacement is a term that refers to:

options.text: Taking up of the vagina as the cervix shortens
A feeling of relief experienced by the woman
Shortening of the cervix as the vaginal canal widens

questions.explanation: Effacement is the thinning and shortening of the cervix.
questions.hint: The cervix 'disappears' or merges.

questions.question: The three (3) bones that form the vault of the fetal head are:
questions.explanation: The vault consists of frontal, parietal, and occipital bones. Option A is the only one listing three actual bones (though temporal is lateral). Other options list sutures (coronal, lambdoidal) or regions (sinciput).
questions.hint: Identify the option that lists only bones.

questions.question: Which of the following are some of the pillars of safe motherhood?

options.text: Preconception care, essential obstetric care, child survival
Home visiting, school health, post abortion care
Post abortion care, pre-conception care, focused antenatal care
Essential obstetric care, accessibility to health services, home visiting

questions.explanation: Key pillars include Family Planning (Preconception), ANC, Safe Delivery, and Post-abortion care.
questions.hint: Post-abortion care is a key pillar often missed.

questions.question: The diameter for the normal pelvic cavity is:
questions.explanation: The cavity is circular, and all diameters (AP, Oblique, Transverse) are approximately 12 cm.
questions.hint: It's a perfect circle.

questions.question: The requirements for home visiting include:
questions.explanation: These are the standard recording tools needed.
questions.hint: Basic stationery.

questions.question: The four (4) sutures of obstetric importance are:
questions.explanation: Frontal, Sagittal, Coronal, and Lambdoidal are the sutures. Occipital and Temporal are bones.
questions.hint: Identify the list that contains only sutures.

questions.question: The layers of the uterus systematically include:
questions.explanation: From outside to inside: Perimetrium (outer), Myometrium (middle), Endometrium (inner).
questions.hint: Outside to Inside.

questions.question: The menstrual cycle is controlled by the following hormones:
questions.explanation: Estrogen and Progesterone regulate the uterine cycle.
questions.hint: The ovarian hormones.

questions.question: The first midwives in Kenya were trained at:
questions.explanation: Tumutumu is historically credited with early midwifery training.
questions.hint: A historical mission hospital.

questions.question: Mrs. X 32 years old para 2+0 in third trimester visits clinic with lethargy, glossitis and gingivitis. Lab shows enlarged RBCs (megaloblasts). The likely anemia is:
questions.explanation: Megaloblastic anemia in pregnancy is most commonly due to Folate deficiency (increased demand).
questions.hint: Enlarged red blood cells = Megaloblastic.

questions.question: A midwife should watch out for the following complications in a woman diagnosed with polyhydramnios:

options.text: Cord presentation, placenta praevia, premature rupture of membranes
Postpartum haemorrhage, premature labour, cord prolapse
Placenta abruption, prolapse of the uterus, congestive cardiac failure

questions.explanation: Polyhydramnios causes overdistension (Premature labor, PPH) and floating fetus (Cord prolapse upon rupture).
questions.hint: Too much fluid stretches the uterus too much.

questions.question: Intrauterine growth restriction commonly seen in pregnancies is associated with:
questions.explanation: Smoking, Pre-eclampsia (vascular constriction), and Multiple pregnancy (competition) are major causes of IUGR.
questions.hint: Factors that reduce blood flow or nutrition to the baby.

questions.question: The midwife suggests to a woman with cardiac disease to avoid prolonged pushing (Valsalva) because:

options.text: It raises intrathoracic pressure, impeding venous return

questions.explanation: Valsalva maneuver increases intrathoracic pressure, reducing venous return. When released, the sudden rush of blood can overload a compromised heart.
questions.hint: It strains the heart by messing with pressure in the chest.

questions.question: During vacuum extraction, the center of the cup should be placed over the flexion point located:

options.text: Along sagittal suture 3cm posterior to anterior fontanelle
On sagittal suture 3cm anterior to posterior fontanelle

questions.explanation: The flexion point is on the sagittal suture, 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle.
questions.hint: Near the back soft spot.

questions.question: A woman at 37 weeks with ruptured membranes for 20 hours should be assessed for:
questions.explanation: Prolonged rupture > 18 hrs increases risk of chorioamnionitis (infection), signaled by fever.
questions.hint: Infection risk.

questions.question: Which nursing care is appropriate for a family dealing with perinatal grief? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Offer emotional support and extend visiting hours
Help create memories (foot prints, lock of hair)
Discourage them from seeing the baby to prevent pain
Quickly remove the baby from the room

questions.explanation: Creating memories and allowing flexible visitation/support are key therapeutic interventions for grief.
questions.hint: Support and memories help processing.

questions.question: Fetal Alcohol Syndrome is:

options.text: A pattern of birth defects, learning and behavioral problems
A group of physical defects only

questions.explanation: FAS is a comprehensive syndrome affecting physical development, intellect, and behavior.
questions.hint: It affects body and brain.

questions.question: Immediately after delivery of the first twin, why check that the IV line is running?

options.text: Augment labor if contractions are not adequate

questions.explanation: Contractions often pause after the first twin. Oxytocin augmentation may be needed to deliver the second twin and prevent atony.
questions.hint: To keep the labor going for baby #2.

questions.question: The drug of choice for Severe malaria in pregnancy is:
questions.explanation: Parenteral Artesunate is the first-line treatment for severe malaria in pregnancy.
questions.hint: It is usually given IV.

questions.question: Select three (3) components of preconception care for a woman desiring a baby.
questions.explanation: Key components: Screening/Managing conditions, Folic Acid (Neural tube protection), and Lifestyle changes.
questions.hint: Preparing the body before getting pregnant.

questions.question: Identify four (4) physiological changes on the breasts of a pregnant woman.
questions.explanation: Breasts prepare for lactation: they grow, darken, glands enlarge, and produce colostrum.
questions.hint: Think visual and functional changes.

questions.question: Select five (5) signs of an impending eclampsia episode.
questions.explanation: These signs indicate cerebral irritation and imminent seizure.
questions.hint: Signs that the brain is irritated by high BP.

questions.question: Select five (5) key features during labor that would require stopping a syntocinon drip.
questions.explanation: Syntocinon must be stopped if the uterus is overstimulated (hypertonus/tachysystole) or the baby is distressed.
questions.hint: Signs of overstimulation or danger.

questions.question: Match the observation of liquor amni with its plotting code on the partograph:
questions.explanation: Standard codes: I (Intact), C (Clear), M (Meconium), B (Blood), A (Absent).
questions.hint: The first letter often matches the condition.

questions.question: Select the temporary structures found in fetal circulation. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: These structures shunt blood to bypass the liver and lungs, and close after birth.
questions.hint: Structures unique to the fetus.

questions.question: What are the risks associated with External Cephalic Version (ECV)? (Select 4)
questions.explanation: Turning the baby can mechanically cause separation of the placenta, cord issues, or distress.
questions.hint: Physical manipulation risks.

questions.question: Which aspects of the 'Warm Chain' are applied upon delivery? (Select 4)
questions.explanation: Steps to prevent heat loss include room temp, drying, KMC, and feeding. Bathing is delayed.
questions.hint: Keep baby dry and close to mom.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for repairing a 2nd degree perineal tear in the correct order:

items.text: Examination & Identify apex of vaginal tear

questions.explanation: Repair proceeds from inside out: Vagina -> Muscle -> Skin. Preparation comes first.
questions.hint: Inside to outside.
